trial_identification.studytitle: Posturography as Biomarker of Oculomotor and Postural Control Integration
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Posturography as Biomarker of Oculomotor and Postural Control Integration

interventions.interventions:
Other interventions - posturographic evaluation
Experimental: subjects - participant undergoing posturographic evaluation
Other interventions: posturographic evaluation subjects will undergo CDP testing using one of the ext_mCTSIB tests without (baseline) and with oculomotor task

primaryOutcome.outcome: Stability Score - The Stability Score (calculated as percentage ratio of the actual sway and the theoretical limit of stability) will be used to investigate if there is any difference between the test without and with oculomotor task. Statistical tools such t-tests and correlation coefficients will be used to assess if there is a difference between the two tests

secondaryOutcome.outcome: average velocity moment [mm^2/s] - The average velocity moment (calculated as as the product of sway velocity path length) will be used to investigate if there is any difference between the test without and with oculomotor task. Statistical tools such t-tests and correlation coefficients will be used to assess if there is a difference between the two tests

sway path length [mm] - The sway path length (the distance traveled during the test) will be used to investigate if there is any difference between the test without and with oculomotor task. Statistical tools such t-tests and correlation coefficients will be used to assess if there is a difference between the two tests

frequency content [Hz] - The frequency content (calculated using FFT) will be used to investigate if there is any difference between the test without and with oculomotor task. Statistical tools such t-tests and correlation coefficients will be used to assess if there is a difference between the two tests

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - subjects suffering from pathology known to affect balance

recruitment.hospital: Carrick Institute for Graduate Studies - Hampton

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Determine the effects looking in certain direction or moving the eyes in a certain way have on the ability of a subject to maintain equilibrium in different circumstances (eyes open/closed, and standing on hard or compliant surface, with the head straight or rotated right or left, flexed or extended).
